description:
Cebus albifrons, commonly known as the white-fronted capuchin, is a species of New World monkey found in the tropical forests of South America. It is a member of the capuchin monkey family (Cebidae) and is known for its distinctive white facial markings and robust build.

The Cebus albifrons is a medium-sized primate, typically weighing between 2.5 to 4 kilograms. It has a rounded head, a short muzzle, and a well-developed brow ridge. The fur is typically brown or grey in color, with a distinctive white patch on the forehead and around the eyes, giving the species its common name.

These monkeys are highly intelligent and social, living in groups of up to 40 individuals. They are primarily arboreal, spending most of their time in the trees, and are known for their dexterous manipulation of objects and problem-solving abilities. Their diet consists of a variety of fruits, leaves, insects, and small vertebrates.

Cebus albifrons plays an important role in the ecology of the tropical forests it inhabits, serving as seed dispersers and contributing to the overall biodiversity of the ecosystem. However, the species is threatened by habitat loss and fragmentation due to deforestation, making it a species of conservation concern.
